title: uVisor: Fix 'publish' and core libs dependencies
body:
## Description
Fix `uvisor` build issues observed with GNU Make 4.2.1, caused by missing dependencies and wildcard patterns in core libs targets' pre-requisites.

Fixes issue #3905.

Tested successfully for building `uvisor` and `mbed-os` with GNU Make versions 4.2.1 and 3.81, with GCC_ARM toolchain version 6.3.0.

title: Uvisor importer: Build fails with GNU make 4.2.1
body:
### Description
- Type: Bug
- Priority: Minor

---------------------------------------------------------------
## Bug

**Target**
Any supported by `uvisor`.

**Toolchain:**
GCC_ARM (required for building `uvisor`)

**Toolchain version:**
`6.3.0`

**mbed-cli version:** 
`1.0.0`

**mbed-os sha:**
`b2726470f Merge pull request #3880 from adustm/fix_can2_only`

**Expected behavior**
Building `uvisor` succeeds, independently of the `make` version in use.

**Actual behavior**
Building fails with `GNU Make 4.2.1`.
Building succeeds with `GNU Make 3.81`.

**Steps to reproduce**
* Using `GNU Make 4.2.1`.
* Fetch a clean `mbed-os` repo.
* Build `uvisor`with:
`make -C mbed-os/features/FEATURE_UVISOR/importer`
* Note the build failure.

Build failure:
```
# Copying licenses
cp TARGET_IGNORE/uvisor/LICENSE* ../targets/TARGET_UVISOR_SUPPORTED
make: *** No rule to make target 'TARGET_M3', needed by 'publish'.  Stop.
make: Leaving directory '/home/rps/scm/rps/iot/arm_mbed/rps_tests/mbed-os-example-uvisor/mbed-os/features/FEATURE_UVISOR/importer'
```

NOTE: After the error, doing `make` again does succeed. 

**Preliminary Analysis**
Check the `features/FEATURE_UVISOR/importer/Makefile` file:
```make
TARGET_M%: $(TARGET_SUPPORTED)/*/*/*_cortex_m%*.a
	@printf "#\n# Copying $@ files...\n"
	mkdir $(foreach file,$^,$(dir $(file))$@)
	$(foreach file,$^,mv $(file) $(dir $(file))$@/lib$(notdir $(file));)

publish: rsync TARGET_M3 TARGET_M4
```

It seems that the target `TARGET_M%` depends on outputs created by the `rsync` target. These outputs are the `$(TARGET_SUPPORTED)/*/*/*_cortex_m%*.a` files.
 However, there's no explicit dependency set between them in the `Makefile`.

The `publish` target needs `rsync` and both `TARGET_M3` and `TARGET_M4`, but there's nothing preventing `make` from trying to do, e.g., `TARGET_M3` before `rsync`.

Additionally, the wildcard/pattern expansion should be performed before actually creating the targets, so for the `TARGET_M%` rule, that will happen at a time where the required files (`$(TARGET_SUPPORTED)/*/*/*_cortex_m%*.a`) were not created yet, causing no rule definition for the targets M3 nor M4. I believe it is this that is causing the problem.
This also explains why the second `make` does succeed: at that 2nd run, the required files are already there. But if you run a 3rd time, it will fail again, a 4th time will succeed again and so on.

I don't know exactly why this doesn't happen with `GNU Make 3.81`. The only explanation is that it is only doing the expansion when the `publish` target is being executed. 

The missing explicit dependencies between `TARGET_M%` and `rsync` is also a problem, because even with `GNU Make 3.81`, the build can fail when we use `make -jN` (with N > 1).

I have a tentative solution for both the problems described. Will submit it through a pull request.

title: Fix heap and stack size for NUCLEO_F746ZG
body:
## Description
NUCLEO_F746ZG has 319K RAM. But heap size is set to 32K. It is less than 64K minimum required for mbed-tls tls-client example. Moreover, the comment in the linker script says heap is 1/4 and stack is 1/8 of RAM. This is not true. 1/4 of RAM is 79K and 1/8 is 39K. Hence updating heap and stack sizes to correct 1/4 and 1/8 respectively.

the TxData or RXData to be zero which allows receiving or sending

title: Prevent underflow in heap size calculation
body:
If the free memory on a device is small enough then the calculation to determine heap size could underflow to a large value. If this happens then malloc will never return failure and instead will cause a crash on allocation. This patch prevents the underflow so malloc works as expected even with low amounts of free memory.

This resolves #3210

`python-levenshtein` in many environments.

title: I2C constructor failure on K64F when using PinName PTA14
Use PATH env variable when gcc found in PATH
body:
Resolves the github issue #3790: Blinky fails to build (on Mac) after
addition of linker script preprocessing feature. Paraphrasing, this
issue is that Homebrew on mac does not install `arm-none-eabi-gcc` in
the same location as `arm-none-eabi-cpp`, the C Pre-Processor. The tools
prior to this commit, and after turning on the pre-processing of the
linker-script will fail on any Mac homebrew installed toolchains.

This commit resolves the above issue by allowing the toolchain's path to
the executable to remain empty after a call to `check_executable`. When
this path is empty, the tools will search the PATH environment variable
for the executable.

## TODO

- [x] Unit test to verify that this problem can never happen again.

title: lwip shouldn't use rand() for port or sequence number randomisation (or at all in general)
body:
### Description
- Type: Enhancement
- Priority: Major

----------------------------------------------------------------
## Enhancement

**Reason to enhance or problem with existing solution**
When using an application using TCP socket, I expect port numbering to start from different port between resets. Currently TCP socket ports always start from same number. This is because lwip uses rand() and srand is initialized to 1 by default in standard library. This results sometimes in unexpected behaviour when using 0 as local port and resetting the device since the previous TCP stream is left open and new one is attempted to open with same port number, depending on network and sequence numbers this might be ok or it might result in connect failing.

However as a user of mbedOS TCPSocket it is not obvious that if I pass in 0 as local port that I also would have to call srand with a random value to get different initial port. Even if a user would know to call srand, they would also have to know that no library is also calling srand with some constant value before the port is randomized.

**Suggested enhancement**
Use another method of random number generation within lwip, for example randLIB, so that behaviour is not dependent on application or other libraries.

title: Socket attach funciton bug
Release candidate for mbed-os-5.4.0-rc2
Remove debug links to printf/exit in NDEBUG builds
body:
Allows development of small applications where stdio is avoided, also optimizes out debug strings and format arguments.

~Biggest change is that `exit` is no longer called. Not sure if that's important (destructors?).~

~Another change to note is that the linkage of `error` is now the same as `debug` (always inlined). This is important to optimize out error strings, but removes the ability for applications to substitute in their own error function.~

EDIT: Only debug is optimized out now. As @pan- pointed out, error can be removed by redefining the function in user code. There's no real benefit to optimizing out error except for consistency, but that comes at the cost of preventing users from redefining the error function. An update to the error function can come at a later date if we find it necessary.

title: DISCO_F469NI: allow the use of CAN2 instance when CAN1 is not activated
body:
## Description
On STM32F4 family, the CAN2 hw instance is using CAN1's filters.
HAL_CAN1_CLOCK_ENABLE must be activated.
This modification is not impacting other STM32 families behavior

## Status
**READY**

## Migrations
NO

## Steps to test or reproduce
Use the can autoloop test with only CAN2 activated on DISCO_F469NI
(test name **MBED_A27**, with `CAN can1(PB_5, PB_13);` instead of `CAN can1(PB_8, PB_9);`)
Without the patch, the` can.read `does not work (only write works) and MBED_A27 test is failed
With the patch, can.read works and MBED_A27 test is a success

title: Deprecated `toolchain.h` warnings when compiling mbed TLS examples.
body:
### Description
- Type: Bug
- Priority: Minor

When compiling any of the examples in mbed-os-example-tls, the following compilation warning is repeatedly printed:
```
[Warning] toolchain.h@23,0:  #1215-D: #warning directive: toolchain.h has been replaced by mbed_toolchain.h, please update to mbed_toolchain.h [since mbed-os-5.3]
```
It seems that the `toolchain.h` file has been renamed, but not all `#include` directives to it have been directed. I did a quick grep and found at least four of these, but perhaps there are more:

```
./benchmark/mbed-os/drivers/FileLike.h:19:#include "platform/toolchain.h"
./benchmark/mbed-os/features/FEATURE_BLE/source/BLE.cpp:30:#include <toolchain.h>
./benchmark/mbed-os/platform/platform.h:28:#include "platform/toolchain.h"
./benchmark/mbed-os/targets/TARGET_Atmel/TARGET_SAM_CortexM0P/drivers/system/system.c:48:#include <toolchain.h>
```

I think that these `#include` preprocessor directives should be updated to `mbed_toolchain.h`.

---------------------------------------------------------------
## Bug

**Target**
K64F

**Toolchain:**
GCC_ARM and ARM

**Expected behavior**
Deprecated warnings should not be displayed during the compilation process

**Actual behavior**
The following compilation warning is printed many times:
```
[Warning] toolchain.h@23,0:  #1215-D: #warning directive: toolchain.h has been replaced by mbed_toolchain.h, please update to mbed_toolchain.h [since mbed-os-5.3]
```

**Steps to reproduce**
* Clone the mbed-os-example-tls repo
* Update the mbed-os.lib file to point to the mbed-os-5.4.0-rc1
* Deploy mbed-os
* Compile any of the examples for K64F using the following command:
```
mbed compile -t GCC_ARM -m K64F
```

title: Add post-build hook white-list to exporters
body:
We have scripts (written in python) that are run after a binary image is
created in the tools. These scripts are not really exportable, as they
are part of the tools and may include and use any bits of python code
they please. So we don't export them. This patch disables export
combinations that would not work because the post-binary hook is not
exported. A white-list is used for forward compatibility.

title: Increase HEAP size for UBLOX_EVK_ODIN_W2 and NUCLEO_F429ZI
body:
Notes:
* Pull requests will not be accepted until the submitter has agreed to the [contributer agreement](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md).
* This is just a template, so feel free to use/remove the unnecessary things

## Description
mbed-os-example-tls/tls-client example fails on UBLOX_EVK_ODIN_W2 and NUCLEO_F429ZI for IAR due to out of memory issue. 
Both the boards have 191K RAM. But heap size is set to 0xC000 (48K). This is fine with GCC_ARM and ARMCC compilers as heap can grow. But IAR has fixed heap. Since tls-client example runs fine on K64F x IAR. The heap size should atleast be 0x10000 (64K). title: Filesystem: Revert deprecation of FileHandle
body:
As identified by @hasnainvirk, @kjbracey-arm, the FileHandle and FileBase serve two separate functions and their integration is limiting for certain use cases.

FileLike is actually the redundant class here, but the multiple inheritance it provides is used as a hack by the retargeting code to get at the FileHandle implementation bound to the FileBase name.

It may make more sense for the FileBase to inherit from FileHandle, (with perhaps a different name), but rather than explore the possibility, this will just restore the previous hierarchy.

cc @simonqhughes, @hasnainvirk, @kjbracey-arm

title: nRF52 timer problem
body:
### Description
I'm trying to get the [BLE_Button example](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os-example-ble/tree/master/BLE_Button) working with low power enabled. Based on the answer to [this question](https://developer.mbed.org/questions/77180/using-power-management-API-such-as-sd_ap/) I compiled the example code with RTOS disabled (by adding ```.mbedignore``` as suggested). Power consumption went down as expected but the LED stopped blinking after a couple of hours of running. This makes the BLE unusable on nRF52 for any practical purpose because either it has too high power consumption or stops working after a few hours.

- Type: Bug
- Related issues: #1533, #1378 ?
- Priority: Blocker

---------------------------------------------------------------
## Bug

**Target**
NRF52_DK

**Toolchain:**
GCC_ARM

**Toolchain version:**
gcc-arm-none-eabi-4_9-2015q3

**mbed-cli version:** 
0.9.10

**mbed-os sha:**
5faf4b2 Merge pull request #3837 from ARMmbed/release-candidate

**Expected behavior**
BLE_Button example should keep working with low power enabled.

**Actual behavior**
After some time the LED stops blinking. The BLE interface still works, i.e. I can connect to the device and read characteristics correctly. When there is some BLE activity the LED blinks once or twice. It seems that the ```EventQueue``` stops calling the ```blinkCallback()``` function.

This happens after a couple of hours of running. It seems that the exact time required depends on the on the event dispatch frequency:
```
eventQueue.call_every(n, blinkCallback);
```
If ```n``` is 50, LED stops blinking after 8200 seconds, if ```n``` is 20, it stops after about 6670 seconds.

**Steps to reproduce**
Download the official BLE_Button example, disable RTOS by adding the following ```.mbedignore``` to the project and compile the code.
```
mbed-os/rtos/*
mbed-os/features/FEATURE_CLIENT/*
mbed-os/features/FEATURE_COMMON_PAL/*
mbed-os/features/FEATURE_UVISOR/*
mbed-os/features/frameworks/*
mbed-os/features/net/*
mbed-os/features/netsocket/*
mbed-os/features/storage/*
```
**Additional Comments**
I have been trying to make BLE examples work with low power for a few days now using various methods. I tried using ```waitForEvent()``` and Tickers with a very similar result. It seems that some low level code interfacing the nRF52 timer might be buggy in some way.

title: Ignore build directory from scan resources
body:
This is a bug fix for the following bug (Github issue https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-cli/issues/437):

If two builds were run specifying a non-default build folder, the second
build would fail to link with duplicate symbols and may not fit on the
device. The root of this problem is that these non-default build folders
are not ignored by scan-resources, and therefore included in the build.

We fix this bug by ignoring the build directory passed into the tools.

title: STM32: change spi error to debug warning
body:
This is the proposed fix to issue #3849 

## Description

In case the selected frequency is higher than the requested one, it is
better to send a debug warning rather than an blocking error.

In case of such warning, user may need to redefine the clock tree setting
at higher level (reducing peripheral's input clocks during init phase).


This will avoid to block basic operations that would work anyway with a frequency higher than the requested one.

title: Cannot clone mbed-OS in Windows if PATH length is already too long
body:
Within mbed-OS longest filename is 165 characters.
Windows API allows only 260 characters.
https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa365247(VS.85).aspx#maxpath


|length| file name|
|------|----------|
|155|`./mbed-os/features/FEATURE_UVISOR/targets/TARGET_UVISOR_SUPPORTED/TARGET_STM32F4/TARGET_RELEASE/TARGET_M4/libconfiguration_stm32_cortex_m4_0x10000000_0x0.a`|
|157|`./mbed-os/features/nanostack/FEATURE_LOWPAN_BORDER_ROUTER/TOOLCHAIN_GCC/TARGET_LIKE_CORTEX_M0/libnanostack_arm-none-eabi-gcc_Cortex-M0_lowpan_border_router.a`|
|157|`./mbed-os/features/nanostack/FEATURE_THREAD_BORDER_ROUTER/TOOLCHAIN_GCC/TARGET_LIKE_CORTEX_M0/libnanostack_arm-none-eabi-gcc_Cortex-M0_thread_border_router.a`|
|163|`./mbed-os/features/FEATURE_UVISOR/targets/TARGET_UVISOR_SUPPORTED/TARGET_ARM_BEETLE_SOC/TARGET_DEBUG/TARGET_M3/libconfiguration_beetle_cortex_m3_0x20000000_0x140.a`|
|165|`./mbed-os/features/FEATURE_UVISOR/targets/TARGET_UVISOR_SUPPORTED/TARGET_ARM_BEETLE_SOC/TARGET_RELEASE/TARGET_M3/libconfiguration_beetle_cortex_m3_0x20000000_0x140.a`|

So cloning the application `mbed-os-example-mesh-minimal` requires already 193 characters.

Should we limit the PATH lengths for mbed-OS to allow more flexibility for users? We are now forcing users to work nearly the root folder of `C:\`

Also, this is a problem of some CI jobs, because they use `C:\WB\<job name>\<branch name>` which easily is close to 100 characters.

title: Add nRf52840 target
body:
## Description
Introduce NRF52840_DK target. It include support for nRF52840 SoC basing on nRF5 SDK v 13. Source codes of new target are on path https://github.com/nvlsianpu/mbed/tree/nRF52840_target/targets/TARGET_NORDIC/TARGET_NRF5_SDK13 and https://github.com/nvlsianpu/mbed/tree/nRF52840_target/features/FEATURE_BLE/targets/TARGET_NORDIC/TARGET_NRF5_SDK13. Allow to redefine nRF's PSTORAGE_NUM_OF_PAGES outside of the mbed-os
body:
## Description
By default the number of pstorage pages is set 1 and all addresses are calculated in the pstorage module accordingly. Nordic recommends changing this macro to whatever number is suitable for the app ([see this answer from Petter Myhre](https://devzone.nordicsemi.com/question/53066/what-will-be-the-starting-address-of-pstorage-page-how-we-can-change-it/?answer=53085#post-id-53085)) which is not quite elegant given that pstorage_platform.h is part of the mbed-os repo. With this modification you can e.g. define PSTORAGE_NUM_OF_PAGES on the command line, however note that you should rebuild mbed-os with this setting as it affects pstorage_platform.c.

This patch modifies the source for both nRF51 and nRF52 families.

title: lwip: Renamed header files to have lwip prefix to avoid name conflicts
body:
Currently conflicts with standard header errno.h. Results in a compilation error for IAR if user attempts to assign the standard errno.

Caused by these prs:
- https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/pull/3762 STORAGE: Merging feature-storage branch commits to master
- https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/pull/3721 Lwip 2.0.1 stable

As far as I can tell the only solution is to rename the problematic file (lwip/errno.h). Let me know if anyone can think of another solution.

This pr updates all lwip header files with the lwip prefix for consistency. This is already the case for source files for unrelated issues with IAR.

Script (yes I should learn perl...):
``` bash
PREFIX=lwip
FILES=$(find features/FEATURE_LWIP/lwip-interface/lwip/src/include/lwip -type f -a -name '*.h' -a ! -name ${PREFIX}'*')
for i in ${FILES} ; do git mv $i $(dirname $i)/${PREFIX}_$(basename $i) ; done
sed -i 's/#include "\(.*\)\<\('$(python -c 'print "\|".join(f.split("/")[-1][:-2] for f in __import__("sys").argv[1:])' ${FILES})'\).h"/#include "\1'${PREFIX}_'\2.h"/' $(find -regex '.*\.\(h\|hpp\|c\|cpp\)')
```

cc @sg-, @bridadan, @kjbracey-arm, @mikaleppanen

This patch brings up timeouts for ntetwork tests 20s -> 60s

title: STM32F103 Nucleo CAN init hangs
osMessageCreate will return NULL when enable DMBED_HEAP_STATS_ENABLED
Generic CallChains
body:
### Make CallChain class generic so that it can be used with different Callback templates.
- Type: Enhancement

----------------------------------------------------------------
## Enhancement

**Reason to enhance or problem with existing solution**
CallChain classes are needed with function prototypes other than void(void).

**Suggested enhancement**
Expand definition of CallChain class similar to the Callback class with templates for
- R(A0, A1, A2, A3, A4)
- R(A0, A1, A2, A3)
- R(A0, A1)
- R(A0)
- R()

Initially possible to return the value of the last caller, but can build in aggregator class, similar to boost::signals2 to allow greater functionality with return values.

**Pros**
New functionality would be additional and should not interfere with existing application code.  

I have been using such an extension of the CallChain with several different callback function prototypes without editing the original non-template class code.

**Cons**
Convention with the templated versions would be slightly different:

- Each template needs its own version of `pFunctionPointer_t` and `CallChainLink`, therefore they need to be encapsulated into the template class.  I think that it should be okay to keep the global `pFunctionPointer_t`, and then each templated CallChain class would have its own typedef'd function pointers, (E.g. `CallChain<int(int, int)>::pFunctionPointer_t`) and `CallChainLink` classes.

Template specialization can be a pain to maintain?

**Other Notes**
The Callback class is fully defined in its header.  I have implemented the entire CallChain template class in the header as well, but I do not know how others feel about this?  I think that the worst thing is that the CallChainLink class is exposed, 

I would like feedback from others before submitting a pull request.

title: EFM32_STK3200 does not compile with mbed-cli
body:
### Description
- Type: Bug
- Priority: Blocker

---------------------------------------------------------------
## Bug

**Target**
EFM32_STK3200

**Toolchain:**
GCC_ARM

**Toolchain version:**
gcc version 5.3.0 (GCC)

**mbed-cli version:** 
1.0.0

**meed-os sha:**
269f58d Merge pull request #3660 from ARMmbed/release-candidate

**Expected behavior**
It should compile

**Actual behavior**
Gives an error, see output below

**Steps to reproduce**
run `mbed compile` with a new project based on the EFM32ZG_STK3200 target. main.cpp is the blinky default program

----------------------------------------------------------------
## Suspicion

The RTC_Conf_CM.c includes the mbed_rtx.h file provided by the platform (at targets/TARGET_Silicon_Labs/mbed_rtx.h). This file includes configuration like:

```
#elif defined(TARGET_EFM32HG_STK3400)

#ifndef INITIAL_SP
#define INITIAL_SP              (0x20002000UL)
#endif

#ifndef OS_TASKCNT
#define OS_TASKCNT              6
#endif
#ifndef OS_MAINSTKSIZE
#define OS_MAINSTKSIZE          112
#endif
```
for all target STKs but the STK3200 as there is no definition for EFM32ZG_STK3200 or a parent. I suspect that it is simply a forgotten definition.

Or the Zero Gecko does not support the RTOS, but then it should give a better error message and configuration.

-----------------------------------------------------------------

Output from `mbed compile`

```
Compile [ 66.2%]: RTX_Conf_CM.c
[Error] RTX_Conf_CM.c@74,3: #error "no target defined"
[Error] RTX_CM_lib.h@438,6: #error "no target defined"
```

title: Add new script to automate compilation of all mbed-os 2 targets in online IDE
Update uVisor to v0.27.0
body:
## Description

This PR updates the uVisor binaries/API files to v0.27.0.

Changelog:

* Re-factored vMPU drivers (internal changes).
* Updated docs.
* Fixed a couple of bugs around vMPU initialization.

## Status

Ready for code review and CI.

## Migrations

This PR only affects people actively using uVisor on a supported platform. Users are affected only if they run with uVisor enabled.

There is a single API change involving the `uvisor_ctx` pointer:

* Previously, this pointer was maintained automatically by uVisor, and it was automatically declared in the translation unit that configures a secure box as `YourBoxContextType * uvisor_ctx`.
* Instead, now we provide a `void * __uvisor_ctx` pointer that the users need to cast themselves to their context type. This ensures that users are aware of the type of `uvisor_ctx` and, most of all, can use it in more than one translation unit.

For a quick fix, just add this line to your existing code:

```C
#define uvisor_ctx ((YourBoxContextType *) __uvisor_ctx)
```

Any ARM small build target (uARM)

**Toolchain:**
uARM

* Create new "Blinky LED Hello World" program target to NXP LPC800-MAX (or any small build target)

* Compile the program and see build information

title: TARGET_NRF5: reworked i2c_api.c
body:
## Description
_i2c_api_ implementation has been changed in order to support single byte reads and writes (the latter are used in I2CEeprom module used in CI tests, and this caused that _tests-i2c-api_ were failing). These operations (single byte transfers) are not possible to achieve with the driver from nrf5 SDK (_nrf_drv_twi_), so the new implementation uses TWI HAL only.

This PR addresses issue #3392, too.

## Status
**READY**


## Migrations
NO

Proposal for a new and clean abstraction layer to be implemented by vendors for the GattClient interface. 
It contains a document explaining the abstraction which can be viewed [here](https://github.com/pan-/mbed/blob/rfc_ble_pal_att_client/features/FEATURE_BLE/rfc/000_pal_gatt_client/readme.md).

title: setting and overriding compilation flags according to target
body:
### Description
- Type:  Enhancement 
- Priority: Minor

I need an ability to override some compilation flags, according to target. I am trying to port mbed TLS over HW cryptographic accelerator, which requires -mfloat=hard as a compilation flag. The only place I saw that this is handle is in tools/toolchains/gcc.py:        
 if target.core == "Cortex-M4F":
   self.cpu.append("-mfpu=fpv4-sp-d16")
   self.cpu.append("-mfloat-abi=softfp")

and it doesn't seem to be able to be overridden.
for the moment, I modified this value, so I won't be blocked, but obviously this is not the way to handle this requirement.

**Target**
Nucleo F401RE

**Toolchain:**
ARM

**Toolchain version:**
uVision 5.2
ARMC 5.06

**Expected behavior**

It compiles for both ARMC and uVision

**Actual behavior**

It works fine for ARMC:
```
 mbed compile -t arm -m nucleo_f401re -c
```

but for uVision:

I'm getting errors:

```
assembling irq_cm4f.s...
rtos\rtx2\TARGET_CORTEX_M\TARGET_RTOS_M4_M7\TOOLCHAIN_ARM\irq_cm4f.s(81): error: A1854E: Unknown opcode 'VSTMDBEQ', maybe wrong target CPU?
```
